newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: NZ First pushes hard line on violent crime.
newsitem.headline: NZ First pushes hard line on violent crime.

text.p: New Zealand First leader Winston Peters on Tuesday hardened his party's law and order line launching a "two strikes and you're out" policy for violent and sexual offenders.
Peters has been pushing the law and order message on the campaign so far, giving audiences at regional venues on his "kiwi spirit" bus tour statistics of the growth in violent crime in their region.

But Peters told a public meeting in the South Island city of Nelson today that law and order and personal security were the "sleeper" issues for New Zealand. He said his party would get tough with violent and sexual offenders.
"A person convicted of a violent and/or sexual offence who then reoffends in a similar fashion will receive a mandatory minimum sentence of 10 years," Peters said.
He said the programme would be backed up with extra funding for adult education and anger management courses in prisons.
Victims would receive reparations, in most cases financial.
New Zealand First would also establish first, second and third degrees of murder, with a minimum 25 year sentence for first degree murder.

But Peters eased off his attacks on the media for not publishing details of a speech on Monday in which he alleged crimes committed by a man charged with sexual violation resulted from the breakdown in the mental health system.
Media outlets have been advised not to publish the details because the case was sub judice, and Peters said "contempt of court is an offence that we all would wish to avoid".

Peters said "legal niceties will not reveal the appalling state of our mental health services". He said he spoke out because he was not prepared to tolerate people dying because of the failing mental health system.
Solicitor-General John McGrath said he intended to look at all aspects of the speech and its reporting.
